Navigate to other release versions of Doxee Platform Process Engine

[6.6](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/process-engine-6-6)

[6.7](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/process-engine-6-7)

Exceptions are raised when errors happen during process execution. Processes can then catch these exceptions to gracefully handle these errors and continue execution. An exception that is not caught will cause the entire process to fail with an error message.

## What’s in an Exception
An exception consists of the following attributes:

- A type

- A message

- An optional cause

- An optional pipeline

An exception’s *type* is a string that classifies the exception in a standardised way and is used

e.g. to define exception connections for specific exception types. By contrast, its *message* is used to display an error message to a human user.

An exception can have a nested exception as its *cause*. This can be useful if a low level exception can be handled partially by the process before throwing a higher level exception that can include the original exception as its cause.

### Exception Types
Exception types are strings that are used to programmatically identify exceptions. Exception connections are assigned to specific exception types, and clients calling a process may use the exception type to decide how to proceed in case the process returns an error.

Exception types are hierarchical: A type named `parent` may be given a sub type by calling the sub type `parent.child`. The dot character is used to separate levels in the type hierarchy. Using it in an exception name therefore always implies a hierarchical relationship between the parts of the type string.

Hierarchical exception types can be used by exception connections and clients that want to handle multiple exceptions of a common base type at once. For example, a connection can be configured for exceptions of the type `io`.* to handle exceptions of any of the following types:

`io.authentication
io.forbidden
io.not_found`Exception types may define additional parent types that are not part of their name. For example, `io.authentication` has io as its parent type by way of its hierarchical name, but also defines the generic type `authentication` as an additional parent.

Exception types do not have to be registered. When throwing an exception, any string may be used as its type. Activities and processes throwing exceptions should therefore clearly document the types of exceptions they may throw.

When registered, an exception type may also define an associated health state. If *error health mapping* is configured, such exceptions will not abort the process when uncaught, but rather set the process' health and use their error message as the health message. Please refer to the Administration Reference for information on how to configure error health mapping.

A list of all registered exception types can be found in the manpages that can be generated by a Process Engine installation.

## Raising Exceptions
Activities and Process Engine itself will throw exceptions if something goes wrong at runtime. However, exceptions can be thrown explicitly using the exception activity from the core module.

To raise an exception, the process has to specify the exception type and message. Optionally, an existing exception variable can also be set as the cause to produce a nested exception.

## Handling Exceptions
Whenever an exception is raised, the Process Engine looks for a matching exception handler by checking the exception connections first on the element that raised the exception, and then on the element’s parents, if the element was nested in a group.

Exception handlers are always evaluated in definition order. Each exception connection defines one or more types of exceptions it is prepared to handle. The first exception connection that matches the type of the raised exception will be used.

An exception connection can specify an exception type either exactly or using the asterisk wildcard (*). A single asterisk matches any type of exception. An exception connection set to handle a specific type of exception will also handle all sub types of that exception. Multiple exception types can be specified by separating them with commas.

> Important

The special exception type system is not handled by * exception handlers. If an exception handler should handle `system` exceptions, the `system` type (or one of its sub types) has to be specified explicitly. A common type of system exception is `system.terminate` (see [Terminate Exceptions](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-process-engine-user-guide-exception-handling-1#terminate-exceptions)).

Here are some examples of exception types defined for exception connections:

`some_exception
another_exception
main_exception.sub_exception
*
main_exception,another_exception,system.terminate`When an exception handler is called, it is automatically passed the exception that triggered it in the variable _exception. This variable can be used in three ways:

- To include it as the cause of another exception.

- To access exception details.

- To access variables from the exception’s pipeline.

### Retry Handlers
In certain cases, it can be useful to retry an operation a number of times before treating it as a permanent error. For example, many I/O timeouts may be dealt with by simply waiting for a moment and retrying the I/O operation.

An exception connection can specify a retry counter and a delay to implement this behaviour. In the simplest configuration, such an exception connection leads *from* the potentially problematic element directly *back to* that same element. It specifies the delay before the element should be executed again (i.e. a delay before the connection is followed) and a maximum number of times this connection may be taken. If, after the maximum number of tries, the exception still occurs, the exception connection will be ignored and the next matching connection (if any) will be used.

Of course, retry connections, like any other connections, may point to a different element as well, allowing for more complex exception handling configurations. The *resetRetryCounter *activity may be used to manually reset the number of retries on a specific connection when necessary.

### Accessing Exception Details
The _exception variable is stored in the internal exception format, which doesn’t allow a process direct access to its attributes. However, an XPath function can be used to get an XML representation of the exception:

`infinica:convert($_exception, 'text/xml')`This will result in an XML structure of the following format:

`&lt;exception xmlns="http://www.infinica.com/process_v2"
           source="..."
           type="..."
           message="..." /&gt;`Assuming that the namespace prefix ipd has been mapped to

`http://www.infinica.com/process-engine` and the exception’s XML is stored in the variable exception, the following XPath queries can be used to access the exception’s attributes:

`$exception/ipd:exception/@type
$exception/ipd:exception/@source
$exception/ipd:exception/@message`### Accessing the Exception’s Pipeline
The exception contains the entire pipeline from the point in the process execution where it was raised. This is especially useful in cases where the exception handler is in a different scope than the element that caused the exception (e.g. outside that element’s group) and has no direct access to the pipeline from the element’s scope.

Variables from within the exception’s pipeline can be accessed using the dot operator:

`exception.variable`## Using Groups for Exception Handling
To handle exceptions of one or more specific types that may originate from multiple consecutive process elements, it can be useful to arrange these elements in a group and connect the exception handler to the group instead of to the individual elements:

![](data:image/png;base64,)*Figure 23. An exception handler attached to a group*

In this case, an exception will cause the process execution to leave the group and jump to the exception handler. Since the handler is outside the group, it will not have direct access to the group’s pipeline; however, the pipeline from the point where the exception originated can be accessed through the _exception variable.

## Terminate Exceptions
When a process is terminated via an external API call (as described in the Administration Reference), the default behaviour is to end the process as soon as possible. The process’s state will be set to `TERMINATED`.

A process definition can override this behaviour by catching exceptions of type `system.terminate` on relevant element and using the exception handler to provide their own shutdown behaviour. If this exception handler ends in a regular end state, the process will end up in the state `FINISHED`, even though terminate was called on it.

If a process wants to cause itself to end in a `TERMINATED` state, it can throw the `system.terminate` exception itself.

> Note

When a user calls terminate on a process, they expect the process to end as soon as possible. A terminate exception handler should therefore generally not prevent the process from terminating, but should just ensure that it ends in a clean manner.

## Error Health Mapping
Exception types may define a health state. If *error health mapping* is activated in the configuration, these exceptions will not abort the process when uncaught, but will instead put it in their associated health state, with the exception’s error message serving as the health message. This allows users to resume process execution using the *recover* operation once the cause of the exception has been resolved.

In combination with *system tasks*, error health mapping can even be used to automatically create tasks which users can complete to resume broken processes. This mechanism allows users to resolve authentication problems by providing updated credentials through a task.

For more information on error health mapping and system tasks, please consult the Administration Reference.
